posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
Potentially you could have a broken sensor wire.  Have you tried a different motor with that spark max?

Edit: I only say that after having broken some NEO550 wires, which are smaller gauge.  Though it doesn’t look obviously broken. Our breaks were near the connector and obvious.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.cooked: We have tried all combinations of new and old motor and motor controllers.

posts.name: PhilBot
posts.cooked:
If you really have tried all combinations of motors and controllers (that is: using two different motors with two different controllers) and are getting the same result, then I wonder if you are configuring the controller to use an external absolute encoder, (like for a Swerve drive) which as we can see, is not plugged in.

I would definately plug a USB into the controller and run REV’s Hardware Client to  see what’s hapenning inside.  You don’t even need the RIO connected.

The first thing I’d do would be to restore factory defaults to the controller and burn that state into the controller.

Then check the error status flags to see if it’s still indicating a Sensor Error.

Phil.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
Almost certainly one of the following:

(1) Broken encoder wire on the motor.  [My goodness, I hate those wires.  Broken wires on 4 separate motors this year] (2) Aluminum shaving in the data port (3) Bent connectors touching in the data port

For (1), the problem is nearly always right at the connector – get your phone camera out, take a photo and zoom in.
When we factory reset the spark max the rotation motor still doesn’t spin.

posts.name: Marcus Kauffman
posts.cooked:
Have you tried plugging the spark into a computer running the rev hardware client? That might give you more information

Note that you will have to disconnect CAN to spin the motor over the hardware client.

We have ran the motor directly through REV client. There are no errors when we do so. There are also no errors until the robot is enabled. We have also tried brand new motors out of the box. We have talked to REV and sent them logs and pictures.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: could you link to your code?

I will, but just a note the driving code is the direct copy from REV. We have not changed any code from when it work at comp. to now (when it is not working).

CODE

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: oh, hm, well, if it works in the REV client but not with your code, even after factory-resetting, then there’s probably something wrong with the code or with the wiring.  have you tried hooking up the controller to the rio PWM outputs to see if you can run it that way with a simple test program?  that test would eliminate some of the possibilities.

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
Your code references an absolute encoder here:

m_turningEncoder = m_turningSparkMax.getAbsoluteEncoder(Type.kDutyCycle);

I’m guessing in your normal setup you have an absolute encoder plugged into the port on top of the SparkMax, probably the Rev ThroughBore encoder.  In your picture, though, it is not plugged in.  I wouldn’t be all that surprised if the SparkMax is giving you a sensor issue because it is expecting data on that port but not getting it.

The orange/magenta blinking is indicative of a sensor fault: https://docs.revrobotics.com/sparkmax/status-led
We have pinpointed the issue, it is the adapters for the through bore encoder to the spark max and now have 3/4 running.

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
That’s good news.

We have found that those adapters can be a bit mechanically finicky.  I recommend making sure they don’t wobble loose from the connection by securing it with a cable tie, or (better in my opinion) a few tight wrappings of electrical tape.

Also, double check that you are using the correct board.   That may be problem with your fourth one.  Rev sells three very similar looking boards that all fit there, but only one works for the job at hand.  Assuming that you are using the Rev Through Bore encoder, this is what you want:

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

And NOT:

NOR:
